commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Where the Magi journeyed from  (4)
2. Follow to the letter?  (5)(4)
3. Rabbit food?  (6)(5)
4. You might get one in a row  (6)
5. Mega-store?  (5)


AFAR
WRITE BACK
EASTER CANDY 
SHINER
HOARD
EOS has been putting in a lot of work lately.

MINIFIG crossing NETI POTS? 
Not a Natick by definition but had me running the alphabet.

A. 11.25
TW 9.51
B 5.19

6011 puzzles solved
100% solved rate
753 current streak 
753 longest streak

No look up

OMG - There is an OREO Way?!!

Plus I just read there is going to be a combination OREO and Reese cup snack product coming out this fall.
REST tickled me.
You don't need to be a Lego aficionado to know MINIFIGs: you just need to have kids. At least that was my experience! üôÇ
7:17 without help üòä
Message for the ‚Äúit‚Äôs all getting easier‚Äù club: This was not easy, in my view! Nice puzzle though.
The exclamation point in the clue for 72 across [This is not working!] doesn't seem right. I get the misdirection, but doesn't it rule out the answer?  Or am I missing something?

50A. Google Maps shows an Oreo Way Skybridge over 15th Street, and somebody apparently called part of lower 9th Avenue Oreo Way, but I've never seen a street sign to that effect over there. Has anyone? https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/factory-oreos-built-180969121/
I don‚Äôt usually have much to say about Monday puzzles but I think this was about as interesting and entertaining a Monday in recent memory. I enjoyed it a lot.

Rebecca, editors, commentariat,

Re: 10D Do we yet have a 
[Salutation in a breakup letter] 
when the recipient is not a male?
Played a little harder than a typical Monday for me.  Found myself jumping around the grid too much to have a good solve time.
Clever clues are always welcome, but an OREO is still an OREO.
This is a perfect Monday puzzle for me, Ms. Goldstein. Thanks for returning back to it to complete it.

A rare incident of what I think is a typo, and a formatting error in the column. Maybe I‚Äôm just parsing it incorrectly, but I can‚Äôt make any sense out of the sentence, ‚Äú What I do miss ease I once felt at food-filled events.‚Äù should it be ‚Äú What I do miss IS THE ease I once felt at food-filled events?‚Äù 
The formatting error is that the below quote is all bold, and should not be:
‚ÄúMinifig, and‚Äù

This may be fixed by the time you read it, fellow crossword puzzle solver.

18D: Reason #43,560 why I hate imperial/customary units (easily guessable in this puzzle, but I‚Äôm definitely not going to remember the exact number of square feet tomorrow).

At least the air temperature here in Tokyo has cooled down to relatively tolerable 27¬∞C; it was sweltering a couple of days ago when I was traveling around a total of about 100 km throughout the day because the Taiwanese art house flick I wanted to see was only showing in Yokohama, and there‚Äôs no point in watching the new brainless but fun dinosaurs-eating-people movie unless it‚Äôs at the IMAX theater that‚Äôs just about as far away from my apartment in the opposite direction. I was able to cool down a bit between the two showings with a 500 ml carafe of (relatively low alcohol) white wine at the cheap Italian place near the latter.

I once had a NETI POT. I tried it, felt like I was drowning, and never used it again. In the 90s, I listened a lot to Pearl JAM, despite not being able to make out half of the words coming out of Eddie Vedder's mouth. Imitating him is easy when you have a mouthful of CHEESE fondue sticking in your palate. (Case in point: https://youtu.be/vE26dVkCvpw?si=77xLzSmcOlElO8yv) I l o v e d the misdirect for REST! [It's not working!] is brilliant ‚Äì and when I saw Rebecca's byline, I thought, "Aha, that explains it!" Rebecca's puzzles and cluing are always chef's kiss. Thank you for offering up a spirited romp!

Minifig had me stumped. What does this have to do with a Lego?  I mean I eat them occasionally so what‚Äôs the big deal. Then I brooded over it for a minute. The lightbulb went off Mini Figure. My kids are 34 & 36 and haven‚Äôt had Legos in the house for years. 
Mildly challenging puzzle today.
First rate fun.  MERCI.

sam,  you are generally wonderful, but your statement:

 31A/26D. [Great Lake with the most consumable 26-Down] can‚Äôt be solved without knowing what 26-Down is, but that clue just says [See 31-Across]

isn't correct.  The answer has four characters.  Only one Great Lake has a name of four characters.

personally, i think that clues using Great Lake references and Erie as the answer should be retired, but then i took an easy A course in college myself.
Cute!
There was a very brief moment when I thought a FREEWIFE was offered by hotels and libraries.

I was too lazy to get out of the recliner, so I did this on the iPad, resulting in a slower pace, since it's one finger at a time. Had the most trouble in the NW, so it was a bit of a slow start, but things got faster after that. Do not have Netflix, so 55A was filled by crosses, but they were quite fair.

Nice puzzle, thanks, Rebecca.

Very fun Monday to cap off my Sunday.

I was stuck a short while on 20A because I missed the musical connection, and figured surely they must taken notes at Eton College. Maybe if they are music majors they make e-ton of notes on tone at Eton. Who‚Äôs really to say.

Interesting how the crossword reflects my life. It's as off the NYT is spying on me.

Today, I actually completed the puzzle while munching on a CHEESE BOARD.

The other day, I was literally crosswording while setting up an INFLATABLE POOL.

And the puzzles are getting too easy. Every day this last week, I've set a new PB.
I can‚Äôt be the only one who lost time by confidently filling 64A with CHarcuterie, can I?

Yummy fill today. But CHarcuterie has the same amount of letters as CHEESE BOARD (ask me how I know) üòâ In addition to those items in the puzzle, personally like prosciutto on mine and salami made into cute little roses üåπ I‚Äôm fancy like that. Add some goat cheese, grapes and nuts and I‚Äôm in heaven. Thank you for this tasty treat, Rebecca!
Happy Monday Crosslandia! üßÄ

Even though NETIPOTS filled in, the N getting me a puzzle done announcement, it was weird enough that I had to look it up. It almost sounds like something I could use one, except my weird symptoms don't match any I saw those pots taking care of. My nose frequently starts running when I am eating breakfast or lunch, but only then.

This was an impressive crossword.  I enjoyed the theme, revealer and general wordplay

Must be difficult to strike the right balance between easy and challenging for a Monday, but I think it was perfect today
11 down - "practice" is a noun; "practise" is a verb, and should have been used in the clue instead, I think.
A little less breezy than recent Mondays. An enjoyable puzzle.

Yes, a lot easier for me today, unknowns solved with crossers, including HORA,  AHI and DAN. 

I've never heard of a cheeseboard with jam and honey. Just cheeses and savoury biscuits, maybe a couple of grapes. I see it as an alternative to a 'sweet' course. 

Nice and doable.

As I was solving, I knew this felt special.  Interesting clues, great fill, a little extra chew.

Rebecca Goldstein!  Of course!  

I should have known.

Now I wish that I had some cheese to nibble on.  

Interesting to read the constructor notes to appreciate how long and hard Rebecca worked to come up with the lovely Monday puzzle.

Zeroing in on a PB; not there yet, but will I ever? Not sure if I ever did a Monday in eight minutes, but that's what's on record.

Very creative cluing for 50A!

I'm guilty of not completely reading clues, so I jumped on FREEGIFT for 4D. The fill brought me back to reality, really!

Just a note about the planned change to the way your comment is displayed when it's a reply to another post:

Currently, you see the original post plus ALL the subsequent replies. Now, though, all you're going to see is the original post, followed only by your reply and nobody else's. This is spoken of as an "improvement."

It sure doesn't seem like an improvement to me! I want to see the whole thread! I already know what MY reply was. I'm not so egocentric that it's the only one I want to see. If I get to the point where that's all that matters to me I might as well just hang it up and retire from human contact altogether.

PLEASE DON'T MAKE THIS CHANGE.

A bit on the tough side for a Monday puzzle but that just made for an enjoyable workout. Five debut answers on a Monday and more than a couple of them that I only worked out from the crosses. No complaints - that's just me. Kind of cute puzzle find today. A Monday from August 22, 2016 by Emily Carroll. Theme answers in that one, straightforwardly clued: BITTERENEMY SALTYLANGUAGE SWEETHEARTDEALS SOURPATCHKIDS and... TASTEMAKERS Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/22/2016&g=6&d=D I'm done....
Fun puzzle‚Ä¶ now I‚Äôm hungry

My only gripe with this is, IIRC from my studies in phonetics (I have degrees in linguistics), MAMA is easier to say than ‚Äúdada,‚Äù not the other way around. This is why a) mama is much more common a word across languages and language families for ‚Äúmother‚Äù than ‚Äúdada‚Äù is for ‚Äúdad,‚Äù and b) mama is more commonly a baby‚Äôs first word rather that ‚Äúdada.‚Äù I think it‚Äôs so fun that these words came from babies just making sounds and the adults assigning meaning to them!

This puzzle could be titled "The Mystery of the Inaptly and Ineptly Named Lego Piece".  Because why on earth would "a piece in the shape of a person or animal" be called a MINIFIG?  A fig is neither a person nor an animal, mini or otherwise.

Beats me.

My other comment on this delightful Monday puzzle, which has interesting fill and almost no names other than ALISON BRIE, is the most peculiar OREO clue:

When did this happen?  I have lived in Manhattan my entire life -- though admittedly not in lower Manhattan -- and I have never heard of an OREO WAY block.  I don't mind so much that OREO has completely taken over crossword puzzles, but I do mind it taking over an entire block of my city.  What colossal nerve!

Other than that, a colorful and crunchier than usual Monday puzzle that I found enjoyable to solve.
MINIFIG and NETIPOTS? Always fun to arrive at the correct answers without knowing exactly why.

CHEESE BOARD?  Not in vogue as described hereabout... a CHEESE ball and crackers or bagel chips gets lots of attention, as do  hummus and spinach dip...but my lovely veggies usually go unnoticed.  (I try and I try, but nobody wants that healthy stuff!)

Someone once gave me a Ritz cracker with orange marmalade on it...which turned out to have horseradish mixed in.  It is still the most horrible thing I've ever tasted.  Trust NOone!

Horror story:  when we children had colds, our mom turned to an old "home remedy"--having you sniff whilst forcing your face down into a basin of very warm salt-water.  "Snook it up!"  A crude forebearer of the NETI POT?  (No thanks.  I still won't put my face down into water.)

Since I complained last week at what I felt was an unfair Monday I will applaud today's perfect Monday.  This one felt wonderfully fair and stimulating.  Maybe I am a glutton and just enjoy food themes more.

I did have to laugh at yet another Oreo sighting tho lol.  Its certainly proving to be the clue of the summer

Delighted by this puzzle by a female who doesn't rely on arcane sports trivia!  The mention of oreo reminded me of my childhood preference for Hydrox cookies, basically the same as oreos, but less sweet, and, interestingly, Hydrox came first.  A google search shows Hydrox basically impossible to find now, although supposedly available from Walmart online, they show them as not available.
Loved all the Fs!   A+ for this delightful fromage homage!

Got off to messy start with "scats" and "scows" at 1A & 1D. That sorted, I was distracted by work, and phone calls, and forgot I was doing the puzzle at all! 
This bodes well for my Monday!

10:49

Difficult for a Monday, imo! I unfortunately had CHEESE PLATE for a while (doubly annoying because it still fit with CROAK) which I had to burn some time on. Fun puzzle and a great way to start the week.
A very nice Monday puzzle with a cute theme.  Bonus points for highlighting ALISONBRIE who was great as Trudy Campbell in Mad Men, one of the few consistently sympathetic characters.

"Should I use a neti pot?"
"Who nose?"

(" 'S not funny!")



(We need you, Mike!)
I live in a houseful of Legos, but have never heard the term "minifig".
I did half of the puzzle this morning, and then had to take my old girl to the vet. She was 14 and time to go,. So I came home and finished the puzzle, very cute.  Just a hard day in other ways.

@Barry Ancona,

To continue our discussion from Sunday, regarding what should be included in the tricky clues section of the Wordplay column.

I did not have to look very far to find inclusion in the tricky clues section answers that were straightforward, but hard:

Column date	Puzzle Date	Straightforward clues
8/9/2025	8/10/2025	4D
8/8/2025	8/9/2025	
8/7/2025	8/8/2025	14A, 23D
8/6/2025	8/7/2025	1D
8/5/2025	8/6/2025	46A, 48D

That is six examples in the last six days.  Now the only argument you have to fall back on is that knowing the context that LAY is a ballad is not hard, which is a purely subjective.
Not much to say about a Monday puzzle, so here's a Fun Fact: In 2007, Lego held a mail-in drawing, and five lucky winners received a solid gold C-3P0 MINIFIG.

My usual late puzzle find. A Tuesday from July 29, 2008 by David Kwong and Emily Halpern. Four fifteen letter theme answers, all of them with "Mediocre" at the beginning of the clue. First example: "Mediocre F. Scott Fitzgerald novel?" THEDECENTGATSBY And the other three theme answers: GOODBARRIERREEF THENOTBADESCAPE OKAYBALLSOFFIRE Don't recall another one quite like that. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/29/2008&g=65&d=A ...
Good one Rebecca -- well done!
Anyone else think this was a bit challenging for a Monday? Nevertheless quite enjoyable, and educational, thank you Rebecca!

Oooh! and one more puzzle find. Thought this one was quite amazing. Anyway - found this one when it dawned on me that... ITSRAININGCATSANDDOGS is 21 letters. And... it was the 'reveal' in a Sunday puzzle from January 15, 2012 by Finn Vigeland with the title: "Weather report." And the clue for that was: "Weather comment represented visually by this puzzle's circled letters" And then all the theme answers were down answers with some letters circled. Here's some examples with the circled letters in parentheses. (P)H(O)N(O)GRAPHNEE(DLE) (MA)SO(N)DI(X)ONLINE ANTI(PERS)P(I)R(AN)T (B)R(O)N(X)BOMB(ER)S (B)R(EA)KIN(G)THERU(LE)S (CA)B(L)ES(I)T(CO)M So those circled letters spelled: POODLE, MANX, PERSIAN, BOXER, BEAGLE and CALICO. Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/15/2012&g=66&d=A ....
Is the Midi ever going to be published on a set schedule?

Entertaining theme and definitely on the tricky side for a Monday - usually I can mostly fill those out on my first pass, but this one had lots of blank space my first time around. A good way to get the brain going for the week!

The comments surprised me, didn't realise people had found today tricky - I'm realising that my current comfort is almost entirely a result of learning from past struggles over the years, recognising a lot of the fill. I definitely picked up NETIPOTS from earlier in this year itself! But even so, loved the cluing and fill of this Monday in particular, would've been a PB if I hadn't made a typo somewhere and couldn't find it for a minute! 
This blog has been so excellent though - I'd love to recommend that everyone try the puzzles from later in the week too with a little nudge from the blog! Everything becomes easier after more and more puzzles, and there's so many fun grids :)

Thinking of our SE Wisconsin solvers! Hope you're doing okay after all the flooding!  It's so awful! üíô Very many of my people are down there (I'm originally from that area), and I've been keeping a close eye on it.

A great Monday puzzle, fresh and just a little bit chewy. Thanks, Rebecca.

Shout out to Heathie and Violet(?) who'd alerted me to the Star Trek puzzle from Sunday 3 August. I'd missed it while traveling. That is definitely a POY contender.
Making CHARCUTERIE fit in the CHEESEBOARD spot was just cruel.... :P

Today took me much longer than recent Monday puzzles have done. I enjoyed the theme. 72 across baffled me. I think it was the exclamation point. I filled 10A with MDS my first time through. DRS is certainly valid, but RN is the degree nurses have, so MD made more sense.

@Sam Corbin

Vegan diet for 10 years - wow!  It‚Äôs been my aspiration since I have empathy for the plight of animals all of whom don‚Äôt have a chance against us but it‚Äôs still just that - an aspiration. So, well done! üëè
Great puzzle! Don‚Äôt attempt to solve on an empty stomach! üòã

I enjoyed the theme of today‚Äôs puzzle.

As a pediatric speech-language pathologist, I have to take issue with 38-Down. ‚ÄúMama‚Äù is not phonetically more difficult than ‚Äúdada.‚Äù In fact, /m/ typically emerges before /d/ in infants and toddlers.
A new Monday record time!  Maybe it was easy even for a Monday or maybe I got lucky.  Either way it was pretty exciting.

Now I want a snack. Very nice quick puzzle. It's fun to be able to fill in all the crosses. I didn't know the actress's name, but the crosses did the work for me. The theme helped too with her last name. Oh how I love cheese! Y'all talk amongst yourselves while I get the box of Ritz and the Costco sliced cheeses. 

Have a lovely evening. Stay safe and enjoy the Dog Days of Summer. ‚úåÔ∏è
Alexa play tyrant by Beyonce..... ONEBYONE

Am I the only person who got minifig, with the immediate visual of a tiny fig leaf for tiny toys and statues. 
Well, it made me laugh anyway, lol!

@Lewis

I miss your optimistic entries you post on a daily basis and look forward to your return.
@Elizabeth Connors -- Thank you Elizabeth!  I'll be returning to commenting the middle of this week...

@Lewis

Great to hear it!
@Lewis, love your weekly round up! When especially smart clues during the week, they are Lewis-possibles in my mind üòä
@Mike ipas/oreo/erie all are used all the time. I like them. They can give you a toe hold into tricky puzzles.

@Andy G

I'd rather have a little more edge.
@Mike Well, she works every morning.
@Eric And she's an early riser.
@Mike the name was mentioned in a game Hades 2 ive been playing and since then ive seen it at least 3 time in the crossword
@Mike  Eos Eats an Oreo and loves her Oboe. There's a theme in the somewhere.
@D M Mojo I don't think I'll ever get close to my Monday best again, 3:33. It was divine.

@Andy G

Same here.  Do you solve your puzzles with a physical keyboard?  We use a tablet with the onscreen keyboard.
@D M Mojo On my phone.

@Canoe-er

I am waiting for OREO to finally be clued ‚ÄúThe twins in ‚ÄòThe Parent Trap‚Äô both eat it with peanut butter‚Äù.

@Bob

Or you could just FIGure it out.
@Bob, I came here to say exactly that!

Petrol,

xwdstats data for the first 90 minutes 
agrees that it was not a easy Monday.

 Global Stats
Difficulty
Average
Median Solve Time
5:14
Median Solver
13% faster
‚ö°70% of users solved faster than their Monday average.
26% solved much faster (>20%) than their Monday average.
üê¢30% of users solved slower than their Monday average.
4% solved much slower (>20%) than their Monday average.

@Barry Ancona Well, then I am particularly proud of myself, as my thought on finishing was, "Maybe the puzzles-are-getting-too-easy crowd knows what they're talking about."  Guess it was just in my bailiwick.

@Bob

I had to read several times. I finally decided that a dramatic pause is needed between Rest   pause for punch line    is NOT working.

I once had a plaque up at work that stated:
Sleep 8 hours
Work 8 hours
But not same 8 hours

The head of the division came to my office and looked around briefly and told me to remove that. I assume my militarized boss requested he visit my office and have me remove it.

@SP
Those are the crosswords I'm used to, although that's one of the easier clues. They can take longer to complete than the typical NYT's ones, and there's not much focus on how fast they take to solve. 
For myself, I wouldn't want to solve crosswords in 7 minutes or so. 
My dad and I used to do a cryptic crossword together and it would take half a day!

@Jane Wheelaghan

Yes I used to do them more frequently and loved them! The Atlantic used to (maybe still does) publish great ones).

@Bob

REST means literally not working. I think the exclamation point is to call out something that is very literal (when the phrase itself might not be), plus the quote itself is something you would say with an explanation point. It‚Äôs almost the opposite of a question mark‚Äîthe question mark means the clue might be a little punny or not literal, while the exclamation point says treat this phrase as literal even though it might not be. Another example, a clue for STRAW could be ‚ÄúSuck on this!‚Äù

@Barry Ancona If you haven't already, see attached from Smithsonian Magazine. I did not know that the Nabisco factory was the origin of the Chelsea Market. https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/factory-oreos-built-180969121/ As a side note, as someone who worked at the corner of Broadway and Wall for over 30 years and lives in Brooklyn, 15th Street didn‚Äôt register as "downtown. " :)
Actually the clue says Lower Manhattan.  That's definitely not 15th Street on my Manhattan map.

@Vaer
Agreed. When people say Lower Manhattan they usually mean FiDi/Battery Park. I would be okay with it meaning anything south of Canal. But not 15th street or Chelsea Market.

Hi Vaer, I guess you missed the link to the Smithsonian article in my OP. Chelsea is uptown from me too, but "Lower" than Times Square (and The Times), so I forgive them. I remember freight trains on the High Line. I've seen plenty of special names added to street and avenue names -- as in the example linked below -- but, as noted in the OP, I've never seen an Oreo Way sign added on either 15th Street or Ninth Avenue. https://archive.nytimes.com/cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/09/17/in-this-corner-finally-its-jerry-orbach-way/

@Barry Ancona
My bad. Sometimes I scroll too fast.

SP,

I did refer to the recipient, not the writer.

@Barry Ancona

Right but I meant in a heterosexual relationship where a man is writing to a woman, they would never write a breakup letter. Way to spoil a punchline.

@Barry Ancona

If John Doe is the generic John, then let's call her Jane.  

Other options: 
Juanita
Jeanne,
Giovanna
Joanna
Johanna
Johanne
Siobh√°n
or Jeannette

@Barry Ancona maybe because it is ‚Äúa‚Äù breakup letter, and not ‚Äúall‚Äù breakup letters, it is okay.

Answer coulda been ‚ÄúDear Jane‚Äù on a Wednesday puzzle and ‚ÄúDear Drew‚Äù on a Friday puzzle.

I'm just on my second cuppa, but I still don't get 10D

Couldn't it be any random name? Is there any connection between breakup letter and John?

SP,

Sorry to spoil your fun, 
but I was asking a serious question.

@Bill in Yokohama

It‚Äôs a convention, breakup letters are colloquially called ‚ÄúDEAR JOHN‚Äù letters.

@SP

TIL, thanks!

@Barry Ancona

Well if we are seriously asking, AI says the official equivalent is a DEAR JANE letter. But like all humor, I think mine has a grain of truth to it; there‚Äôs a reason you don‚Äôt hear about Dear Jane letters very often.

@dutchiris

I was sort of expecting to see Felicia in the list

I'd expect AI to offer Jane (Doe) as the counterpart to John (Doe), but is Dear Jane actually cited (or sighted) anywhere?

Or did women (away in the service) not get dumped by their erstwhile partners? I say "did" because I don't think anyone writes a letter to break up these days, and ghosting seems gender-neutral.

The X-Phile and SP,

I see what they say, 
and I always got the idea, 
but I still don't see one cite.

@Barry Ancona

My article had a citation, but I have no idea whether the citation is legit or not.

SP,

Your article had a footnote that led to another article. That other article had no citation.

WHATEVS.

@JM

I love jumping!!
@dutchiris but is a cigar just a cigar?

@dutchiris 
But this is not a pipe.

@Margaret from Brooklyn
This is a Wendy‚Äôs

@Paul

Sometimes.

@Bill in Yokohama

Movil, actually.
@Nick Wow, haven't been there in ages! If you're willing to trek to Yokohama for art house cinema, you might wanna check out my two guesses https://www.jackandbetty.net/ https://cinemarine.co.jp/
@Nick so you certainly won‚Äôt remember that there are 640 acres in a square mile.   It‚Äôs helpful when they tell us 10,000 acres have burned in a wildfire.

640 acres was easy to remember in Iowa 
when there were family farms. 
Dirt roads every mile, E-W and N-S. 
Four 160-acre farms in each mile-square.

@Nick 
We yanks don't know the number of square feet in an acre either. We just know that it's a pretty big measure of area, and has four letters. ACRE is one of those words--like oreo --that us solvers just have to know.  Fyi, building lots and farm fields are measured in acres.

@Margaret from Brooklyn
Yeah, I‚Äôm a Yank-by-passport myself, so I got the answer immediately. In the real world, outside of crosslandia, though, I tend to think in base-10 (occasionally base-2 if I‚Äôm doing bitwise operations, or base-16 if I‚Äôm feeling hexy). I find multiplying or dividing by powers of ten to be much more elegant and convenient than fiddling around with ‚Äúforty rods to the hogshead‚Äù and such.

@ad absurdum

That's why G*d gave us the hectare. 10,000 square meters = one hectare.

@sotto voce

I thought about using a NETI POT at one time, but it looks like self-inflicted water-boarding.  Your comment confirms that suspicion.
@sotto voce You are so right. You may have already seen this man's attempt to help us through Yellow Ledbetter: https://youtu.be/xLd22ha_-VU Cleared things right up for me.

@The X-Phile
It sounds disgusting to me, would never consider using one. Yuck

@The X-Phile

It's possible I just wasn't able to master the correct way. Still, it was so uncomfortable that I chose to not even try it again, and opted to stay with saline spray.

@Jerry

ROFL! This is so perfect!

I read some of the comments and found this absolutely brilliant one by @zackkahn:

"It doesn't get Eddie Vedder than this." 
üòÇ

@Dan Collins 

You really should stop eating Legos.
@Bruceü§ì

@Dan Collins
I‚Äôm sure you meant to say ‚ÄúLEGO bricks‚Äù‚Ä¶.

pollyq,

Sam "corrected herself," writing: "31A is four letters, and the only Great Lake whose name fits here is ERIE."

But it's the 26D clue that is meaningless without reading the 31A clue.

@pollyq

Ooh, I love Great Lakes clues. I wish someone would do a whole puzzle about them...  Mmm, has someone!? I should find out! 

I recently swapped out my avatar pic but my previous one was me bobbing around in Lake Superior. üôÇ

P.S. Sam, you're always wonderful!!  üôÇ

@The X-Phile

LOL
Today happens to be our 46th anniversary.  I got the DHubby a very special card!  
I simply must share it!

"It's so WONDERFUL being married to the Greatest Spouse in the World!.....


                          Isn't it, Dear?"

@DD

To borrow a phrase, ain‚Äôt no such thing as a FREE WIFE.

@Mean Old Lady
Many congratulations!
@DD üòπ

@Mean Old Lady

When I was dating my wife she gave me a birthday card that said.

"I think a birthday is a perfect time for a naked dance."

In her book Origins of the Specious, Patricia O'Conner says that it was actually British English that changed (spellings, pronunciation, etc.) post Revolutionary War, and that prior to American independence, Britons sounded and spelled more like modern Americans.

@Jane Wheelaghan, very common here in the States. The honey is in a small dish with a tiny spoon, and you drizzle it over the soft, creamy cheeses, like aged Camembert or brie. Often, it is a pice of raw honeycomb. The jam is usually fig, raspberry or blackberry jam, equally good with those same cheeses. Try it, you will love it!

@Danny
Have to disagree with what is harder to say‚Ä¶I have two new mom friends who send me videos of trying (in vain) to get baby to say MAMA. Baby will  scream back DADA! As if to say NO, that is not a word. Its DADA!!!

@Danny

‚ÄòMama‚Äô is most likely more common as the baby‚Äôs first word because, statistically, more languages (at least among countries that publish research on developmental milestones) have their word for ‚Äòmom‚Äô begin with ‚Äòm‚Äô than there are languages whose word for ‚Äòdad‚Äô begin with a ‚Äòd‚Äô (there‚Äôs a lot of competition from tatas, papas, babas, etc. out there). 

Also, since in most cultures the majority of babies still likely spend more time with mom than dad, they see ‚Äòmama‚Äô modeled for them much more often. Plus it‚Äôs likely easier for a baby to notice and try to mimic the mechanics of ‚Äòmama‚Äô vs. ‚Äòdada‚Äô since the lip movement the adult is demonstrating is more overt than their tongue position. 

As for whether ‚Äòm‚Äô or ‚Äòd‚Äô is more difficult to produce by a mouth starting ab ovo, some speech pathologists say that ‚Äòd‚Äô comes more naturally to infants because it mimics the tongue position they produce when self-soothing with a sucking sound/motion, whereas ‚Äòm‚Äô requires more lip control that‚Äôs not acquired by them early on for other reasons. This only holds true for babies, of course. If an adult is relearning speech, for example after a stroke, ‚Äòm‚Äô may be easier to learn than ‚Äòd‚Äô as you posited.

@Danny
My father was a speech pathologist who wrote a book on phonetics. He taught me that ‚Äúdada‚Äù was easier to say than ‚Äúmama‚Äù. He‚Äôs been gone for many years now, so perhaps more recent research aligns with your statement.

@Danny
My kids all said DADA first, but it was simply because I'm way more awesome than their MAMA.

Jeff Z,

She is reading over your shoulder...

@Danny

In reviewing what I could on the internet, it seems at least to be an open question. As a pediatrician, I‚Äôve heard it said that dada comes first for linguistic reasons, and my empirical observations in clinic and with my kids (except one who said ‚Äúdis‚Äù and ‚Äúdat‚Äù for everything for a long time) is that is true. But I don‚Äôt see any firm studies on it. So it could be an old wive‚Äôs tale that‚Äôs perpetuated by confirmation bias. One interesting article I read suggested that babies may say dada first because they see them as a separate entity sooner than moms, that‚Äôs an interesting suggestion‚Ä¶so not to knock your expertise, you could be right.

@Danny I‚Äôm curious how many children you have (if any) and what their first word was? From my limited experience of myself, my siblings and my friends, all of our children‚Äôs first word was ‚Äúdada‚Äù.  Again, my experience is limited to my small circle, but I‚Äôm curious about other experiences.

@SP it‚Äôs certainly an interesting topic‚Äî I‚Äôm not an expert on this particular topic or group of learners (I primarily deal with second language learners), but have a lot of coursework around general speech and language development, and I was always taught that all of the bilabial sounds (/m/, /b/, and /p/) typically develop first. There‚Äôs a lot of people commenting that my assertion was wrong‚Äî I don‚Äôt know if I would concede that, but I‚Äôm sure that despite this being typically the first sounded to develop, it almost definitely not a hard and fast rule. There is so much variability with babies and the speed in order in which they learn new things!

@Solverado part of what I am saying is that the very reason ‚Äúmama‚Äù is common is because all of these cultures did not just randomly decide that that would be the word for mother‚Äî‚Äúmama‚Äù is often the first if not, one of the first sounds that a baby produces, and as a result, a mother would react to that and assign meaning to it that the baby must be talking about them. /p/ and /b/ are some of the next most common and early sounds for babies to produce, which gives us a lot of papas and babas in a lot of other languages in addition to the others you mentioned! So what I mean by interesting is that it wasn‚Äôt that we created a word and then taught it to the baby, but rather baby made a sound, and we reacted to the sound and continued to reinforce it and thus assigned meaning that way!

@EA
"Dada" only requires moving the tongue. For "mama" we need to move our lips and lower our velum. Sounds harder to me.
